channel.description: The top News headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit https://www.smh.com.au
channel.title: Sydney Morning Herald - Latest News

item.dc:creator: Latika Bourke
item.description: If you suspect you or a family member has coronavirus you should call (not visit) your GP or ring the national Coronavirus Health Information Hotline on 1800 020 080.
item.title: Coronavirus updates LIVE: JobKeeper extension urged after 'error' as global COVID-19 cases surpass 5.2 million, Australian death toll stands at 102

item.dc:creator: Bevan Shields
item.description: The Prime Minister's powerful chief adviser drove 400 kilometres to northern England in apparent breach of strict social distancing rules.
item.title: Boris Johnson digs in as coronavirus travel scandal engulfs his controversial chief adviser

item.description: The joyous end of Ramadan is usually celebrated with the coming together of large families and friends in big public gatherings, feasting and exchanging gifts in community centres and halls. This year Eid is different.
item.title: The Muslim community are marking Eid, the breaking of the Ramadan fast

item.description: Follow our rolling coverage.
item.title: Tablet interactive: Coronavirus outbreak

item.dc:creator: Matt Wade
item.description: The case for an eastern seaboard megaregion.
item.title: Why Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane should put an end to old rivalries

item.dc:creator: Wendy Tuohy
item.description: Women experiencing family violence would be able to get help through supermarket safety points under a plan in development by crisis service Safe Steps.
item.title: Plan to help women seek family violence support through supermarkets

item.dc:creator: Wendy Tuohy
item.description: Australian women are suffering more job losses, anxiety and more dire long-term financial damage due to the economic shutdown caused by COVID-19.
item.title: 'This is laying the groundwork for some pretty serious poverty for women'

item.description: Perhaps it's NSW, not Queensland, that should be worried about letting in the hordes.
item.title: Viral state of origin bordering on the ridiculous

item.dc:creator: The Herald's View
item.description: China showed its true colours when in just one week it turned its economic prowess against Australia and its political might against Hong Kong.
item.title: Behind the charm, China is a bully - and we need to sell our wares elsewhere

item.dc:creator: Danny Weidler
item.description: The most delicate negotiation of Greg Inglis' comeback had nothing to do with his deal with Warrington in the UK Super League.
item.title: Modern family: The team behind GI’s rugby league rebirth

item.dc:creator: Zach Hope
item.description: Today begins the holy Islamic festival of Eid, which would normally be celebrated with large family gatherings and feasts.
item.title: An Eid like no other for Victoria's Muslim community

item.dc:creator: Tom Rabe
item.description: Dozens of extra buses are being added to the busiest sections of Sydney’s straining public transport system as hundreds of thousands of students return to school.
item.title: Extra services added to Sydney's straining transport network

item.dc:creator: David Crowe
item.description: The Morrison government will consider giving more help to workers who have been hit hardest by the coronavirus crisis.
item.title: 'How about we don't spend it?': Coalition divided over $60 billion JobKeeper windfall

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: Pokies will return on June 1, but punters will have to adhere to social distancing measures, with machines likely to be separated or every second machine switched off.
item.title: Pubs and clubs seek more tax breaks as they prepare to switch on the pokies

item.dc:creator: Timna Jacks
item.description: Soil being dug up in the heart of Melbourne to build the $6.7 billion West Gate Tunnel has PFAS levels that are 100 times the acceptable amount in drinking water.
item.title: Secret EPA reports reveal PFAS problem on West Gate Tunnel

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: Fears of a booze-fuelled lockdown are fading as new figures show sales of alcohol have plummeted by volume as well as value.
item.title: Some drinking more, but alcohol sales down

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: Sydney landlords have been forced to slash rent by 25 per cent in some suburbs as tenants renegotiate their lease or move out for a better deal.
item.title: 'A very good time to upgrade': Tenants bag bargains as landlords drop rents

item.dc:creator: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
item.description: While some families are delighted schools are back, others are furious that they no longer have a choice.
item.title: 'Don't make my kids guinea pigs': The families refusing to return to school

item.description: With intrastate travel allowed from June 1, motels and motor-inns look set for a surge in popularity.
item.title: Cleaning up: road trips set to make motels the inn thing

item.dc:creator: Tony Blakely
item.description: To eliminate or suppress the coronavirus. Therein lies the tension between the strategies of the states and territories - and whether or not they open their borders.
item.title: States race in the COVID-19 elimination stakes

item.dc:creator: David Crowe
item.description: A new analysis finds the lower penalty rates did not lead to significant new jobs in hospitality and retail.
item.title: Penalty rate cuts did not create jobs: Labor

item.dc:creator: Adam Carey
item.description: Students have been less distracted while learning remotely and produced a better standard of work than normal in many cases, a survey of more than 1100 Australian teachers has found.
item.title: Students less distracted and do better work remotely, teachers say

item.dc:creator: Peter FitzSimons
item.description: It will be a battle for the rights of the few who play golf and the many who don't.
item.title: The golf war will be the great gulf of Sydney

item.dc:creator: Jacqueline Maley
item.description: Allegations of sexual assault against powerful men rarely make the mainstream media without extensive investigation and corroboration.
item.title: #MeToo told us to believe women, so why do feminists discount the claim against Biden?

item.dc:creator: Nathanael Cooper
item.description: Unless social distancing measures are relaxed further, some of the most anticipated shows in the country will struggle to raise their curtains.
item.title: Blockbuster shows won't go on without easing of social restrictions

item.dc:creator: Jordan Baker
item.description: Strict social distancing rules have cut the number of students allowed in boarding houses and drastically limited their freedoms.
item.title: Parents banned, students grounded under new COVID boarding school rules

item.description: McCrindle Research’s Top Baby Name list reveals a jump in unconventional names, particularly for girls, and a growing trend towards gender-neutral names.
item.title: The unique baby names on the rise in 2020

item.dc:creator: Andrew Taylor
item.description: Limited to ten people in the pool at any one time and one swimmer per lane, outdoor pools are grappling with high demand from swimmers.
item.title: Outdoor pools might be open but swimmers can't get a slot

item.dc:creator: Andrew Taylor
item.description: The ski season will start later and visitors are likely to encounter long queues for ski lifts at NSW snow resorts.
item.title: 'Resorts don’t want a Bondi moment': How COVID-19 will affect ski season

item.description: Just because guest numbers are limited, it doesn’t mean the imagination has to be. Ahead, four ideas the kids will love, and some grown-up options for you.
item.title: How to throw a kid's birthday party while socially distancing

item.dc:creator: Lucy Manly
item.description: "He’s a big boy. He knows what he is doing," Jackie Henderson says of Kyle Sandilands, her broadcasting partner of 20 years.
item.title: Jackie O: I'm not Kyle's mother

item.dc:creator: Natassia Chrysanthos
item.description: NSW students are returning to school full-time, but parts of school life such as parent-teacher meetings and the daily school drop-off will look different.
item.title: School is returning full-time from Monday. Here's what you need to know

item.dc:creator: Max Koslowski
item.description: Senior government ministers say they are receiving an unprecedented amount of anti-vaccination correspondence as experts warn of a new wave of vaccination distrust.
item.title: Federal ministers flooded with unprecedented level of anti-vaccination mail

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: Capital city rich-listers have flocked to their holiday homes during the crisis, because if you're going to be locked down, it might as well be in Byron.
item.title: During a rare reprieve from tourists, Byron's locals (and semi-locals) rule the roost

item.dc:creator: Lindy Percival
item.description: We're all eating and watching too much – why not combine the two?
item.title: Five cinematic banquets to feast your eyes on

item.dc:creator: Melissa Singer
item.description: Fashion brands are flocking to video-sharing app TikTok in a bid to win Gen Z's hearts and wallets. In the land of 15-second clips, authenticity trumps a designer label.
item.title: What makes a Gen Z shopper different?

item.dc:creator: Garry Maddox
item.description: As more people cycle to work, a longtime rider and two industry representatives pass on their advice for newcomers.
item.title: From heart attack to daily rider: an insider's guide to bike commuting

item.dc:creator: Riley Wilson
item.description: In lockdown, community gardens are overflowing with sweet potato and spring onions, and curious wildlife is taking to the streets.
item.title: Gardens 'flourishing' and wildlife 'curious' as humans stay home

item.description: Trivia and word buffs: test your knowledge with today's superquiz and Target.
item.title: Superquiz and Target, Sunday, May 24

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: The country's former top public servant Martin Parkinson has urged the government to "go for broke" on skilled migration.
item.title: Migration 'reset' looms in budget as government eyes super-skilled talent

item.dc:creator: Linda Morris
item.description: The state government has provided a lifeline for creative art companies suffering severe financial distress.
item.title: NSW arts companies win $50 million lifeline

item.dc:creator: Adam Carey
item.description: Victoria's education system has an opportunity to harness the lessons of the past two months of enforced remote learning, school leaders say.
item.title: Learning the lessons of the pandemic

item.dc:creator: Zoe Samios
item.description: Despite the unprecedented audience thirst for news, business models are failing and outlets are going bust.
item.title: 'Worst I've ever seen': How COVID-19 accelerated the media industry's woes

item.dc:creator: Michael Koziol
item.description: For some time now I've been convinced the technological revolution is partly geared towards killing off society under the guise of convenience.
item.title: Normalising 'working from home' will be the death of society

item.dc:creator: Andrew Taylor
item.description: Changes to planning rules could provide much-needed support to the ailing arts and entertainment industry.
item.title: Take to the sky: how property development could save Sydney's arts scene

item.description: There’s no doubt this season will be unique, but does that make it inferior?
item.title: In the AFL's history, this season is still far from the weirdest yet

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted by our talented artists, illustrators and cartoonists.
item.title: Best of cartoons, May 24, 2020

item.description: I’ve reflected back on my ideas and realise most lie buried under the piles of Lego, paper and general household debris that is iso-life with children.
item.title: All the things I never got around to actually doing in iso...

item.dc:creator: Clive Hamilton
item.description: China's Belt and Road Initiative agreement with Victoria is the golden fruit of a long process of cultivation of Melbourne’s political elite.
item.title: China has been successful in ramping up its influence in Victoria

item.dc:creator: Zach Hope
item.description: The Andrews government has revealed the locations of 24 new suburban parks, including nine off-leash dog areas, to open from next year.
item.title: More than 20 new parks and off-leash dog areas revealed
